text: in January of this year Salmonella
tainted peanut products sickened over
500 people and were linked to eight
deaths
there was a nationwide recall of over
125 products because peanut paste is
found in everything from candy and
cookies to pet food and energy snacks
investigators tracked the salmonella
outbreak to Pina Corporation of America
a factory in Blakely Georgia
it makes peanut butter for institutions
like schools and nursing homes and
peanut paste for other companies like
Kellogg's the recent outbreak has raised
some alarming questions about food
safety Andrew Martin covers the food
industry for the New York Times I think
we've all come to know that you know you
got to cook a hamburger to 160 degrees
or else you might get e.coli that
chicken has to be cooked through earlier
you could get Salmonella that eggs you
know rags are dangerous but peanut
butter my god you know we peanut butter
all the time you know when your kids my
kids eat peanut butter every day it's
just not something that you sort of
think of as a dangerous product and
there's a growing sense in Washington
that there is something deeply wrong
with the Food and Drug Administration's
oversight of this food supply I think
that the FDA has not been able to catch
some of these things as quickly as I
expect them to catch and so we're going
to be doing a complete review of FDA
operations so where did the system break
down I mean there's many many places the
system broke down you know starting with
the company itself
inspectors can't walk into plants and
say and see Salmonella or they can't see
e.coli they're microscopic well what
they can't see is is you know the most
basic hygiene problems and from what we
know now from what the FDA is revealed
is that this this plant had some very
serious problems in terms of basic
cleanliness
you know roaches crawling all over with
you know slime and the conveyor belts
mold on the floors and you think you
know how could it be that people walk
through the same plan and didn't see
some of this stuff in addition the
company hired its own expect errs who
time after time gave it a superior
rating it's obviously a very good
question how plant with this serious of
of problems could have
continually past audits but it raises
very serious questions in my mind about
you know the the sort of utility of
these audits what's worse in more than
one instance Peanut Corporation of
America tested their products for
Salmonella and got positive results and
when retest came up clean the companies
still sent the products out the federal
government is conducting a criminal
investigation of this company you know I
don't know if they broke the law but you
know the fact is at least according the
FDA they had positive Salmonella tests
and they sent the product out anyway you
know in this case self-regulation didn't
work
where was the FDA I mean ultimately you
need to have a system of checks and
balances and you know if the company is
not doing and if the writers are
enjoying it if the government is not
doing it well then this is what you get
Gardner Harris covers the Food and Drug
Administration in Washington DC
he says the agency is overwhelmed by the
vastness of its duties and it has little
authority to regulate in fact there are
12 distinct federal agencies with some
oversight power over food and this
scattered approach and regulatory
authority over food according to most
outside observers is one of the
principal reasons that food oversight
has been very poor in this country for
instance you know if FDA oversees cheese
pizzas USDA oversees meat pizzas you
know FDA oversees closed sandwiches USDA
oversees open sandwiches and the FDA's
oversight of drugs for instance is very
different than its oversight of food
although I think in the public's mind we
really sort of mix these up so in its
oversight of drugs for instance FDA
assumes that a drug is unsafe unless a
drug maker approves through considerable
research that it is safe on the food
side just the opposite happens actually
food manufacturers get the assumption
that their product is safe and it and it
takes the FDA to prove that it is unsafe
for the FDA to be able to do anything so
the result is that FDA has very little
authority in the food area that issue of
authority is has become an important
part of this debate and nearly all of
the legislative reform proposals would
give FDA much more authority to do
precisely that which is to do sort of
preventive shutdowns of places they
think may be producing contaminated
products several members of Congress
have proposed making significant changes
of the FDA there is an important group
of legislatures who believe essentially
that all FDA needs is more money and
more authority and it and frankly a
little more guts and it will do could do
a much better job overseeing food but
there's another group of legislatures
and they are powerful who believe
fundamentally that FDA is primarily a
drug and device approval agency and that
food
has always been a stepchild at FDA and
always will be and so that there were
answer really is to split off food from
FDA and create its own Institute this
scare involves a lot of children and we
have an administration now that I think
is amenable to these regulatory changes
in ways that the Bush administration
wasn't at bare minimum we should be able
to count on our government keeping our
kids safe when a peanut butter that's
what's a cheats for for lunch probably
three times a week and you know I don't
want to have to worry about whether
she's going to get sick as a consequence
of having having her lunch but the
withdrawal of Senator Tom Daschle's
nomination for health secretary puts a
damper on a quick resolution nothing
major is going to happen at FDA until
the Obama administration gets its
leadership in place I mean you know I
don't think anybody really thinks that
any major legislation on FDA is going to
is going to pass before the summer
you
